The lessons of the Great Recession are clear. Going too small, like in 2009, will lead to a sluggish, years-long recovery. We should listen to the economists telling us to go big in this moment. Manufactured concerns about the debt will only delay relief for millions of families.

I look forward to improving antitrust enforcement this Congress. It is imperative that we ensure markets work for consumers, not just monopolists. It is equally imperative that we not cede this task to the radical left. The consumer welfare standard is essential to both. 5/5

We need the enforcers to (finally) enforce the antitrust laws against those who harm competition and consumers, including Big Tech. But we need to do it in a way that doesn't allow judges to usurp Congress's legislative role. 4/5

Let's also note what the consumer welfare standard is NOT: it is not a narrow concern with price. As Judge Bork wrote, it encompasses ‚Äúinnovation, choice among differing products" and quality. That more than covers the ways in which markets like Big Tech are failing us. 3/5

What is the consumer welfare standard? It's a guardrail that ensures 1) the primary beneficiaries of the antitrust laws are the people, not big business; and 2) that unelected judges are not allowed to use antitrust to advance their own political preferences. 2/5

There‚Äôs a lot of talk about antitrust legislation this Congress. One thing lost in many proposed reforms: the consumer welfare standard is not a get-out-of-jail-free card for Big Tech. We don‚Äôt need to change the law, we need to enforce it. 1/5

Fran‚Äôs family offers thanks for the compassionate care provided by her medical staff and healthcare workers whose efforts filled her life with dignity and hope.

May she Rest In Peace.
There were great demands for her delicious pierogi, lasagna, babka bread, and lemon meringue pie. Frances was an avid lover of animals including her own Victor and Vanessa.

Frances had been recognized in the past by former Governor Mario Cuomo as ‚ÄúNew York Blood Donor of the Year‚Äù. 

She took great pride in her vegetable and flower gardens. She was a great baker and cook.

Frances was a lifelong Greater Amsterdam area resident. She was a member of St. Stanislaus Church and the Ladies Rosary Society; St. Mary‚Äôs Club 60 and a past member of the Montgomery County Women‚Äôs Democratic Club. She was appreciated as an energetic campaigner.
Frances had been employed by the Selective Service System and later worked for the Amsterdam Insurance Agency in Amsterdam, NY until her retirement in 1976.
On June 21, 1947, she was united in marriage to Stanley C. Tonko. They shared 68 years of married life together. Stanley died on June 28, 2015.
Frances was born on April 16, 1921. She was the daughter of Boleslaw and Karolyna Bik Grajewski. She was a 1937 Wilbur H. Lynch High School graduate. She later continued her Post Graduate studies.

Frances G. Tonko, 99, of Princeton Street, Amsterdam, NY died very peacefully on Sunday, January 24, 2021, at the River Ridge Living Center in Amsterdam, New York. https://www.recordernews.com/obits/184908

In the meantime, I want to thank the first responders, Alaska Native leaders, and state officials who have been essential in bringing potable water to Tuluksak. I will continue to keep Alaskans updated as information develops, and relief resources are identified.

Throughout my involvement, I have made it clear to local leaders that I stand ready to help in any way I can. My team and I are currently exploring potential federal funding sources and partnering with local leaders to help in the federal grant application process.

The situation continues to evolve, and although deliveries of bottled water and other drinking water will help alleviate some problems in the near term, long-term solutions and funding will be needed to rebuild water infrastructure and ensure access to clean water for families.

From the moment the news broke, my team and I have been monitoring the situation and communicating with local officials, the Yukon-Kuskokwim Health Corporation, the Alaska Native Tribal Health Consortium, state officials, and Senators Murkowski and Sullivan.
